Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
November 18, 2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not
result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency or tribe, the
agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has
received orientation to the policies of the
borrowing agency.
2 of 3 borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain the required documentation
regarding orientation.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90 calendar days
thereafter.
2

1 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed contained a service plan that
was not completed within the required timeframe. The report dated
05/26/2022 – 06/24/2022 was approved on 07/13/2022, 19 days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION VIOLATION FROM RENEWAL DATED 09/16/2021
CAP RECEIVED 09/17/2021.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional MDHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS FOM POLICY Family Team Meetings
722-6B Types and Timeframes
FTMs must occur within the required time
frames.
Post FTM
Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, to all
participants (in person and by phone), legal parents, and casework
supervisor. These documents must also be uploaded into
MISACWIS. The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of
the FTM.
2 of 21 open case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all required
FTMs were held as required. Report dated 09/2021 – 12/2021, there was
no FTM held for the reporting period. The report dated 06/2022 – 07/2022,
there was no FTM held for this reporting period.
DHHS FOM POLICY REQUIRED SIGNATURE
722 – 08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain signatures
from the following individuals, as applicable: caseworker Supervisor
second line supervisor, when siblings in care are place apart Parents
who are a member of a participating household. Youth ages 14 and
older. Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-ordered
caregivers. Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check
yes or no for the following when signing the treatment plan: I have
participated in the development of the Case Service Plan and the Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
10 of 21 PATP’s reviewed did not contain the required signatures of caregivers,
3

parents, or youth over 14 years old. The boxes were not checked to indicate
that the parents, caregiver, or youth participated in the development of the case
service plan and the Parent Agency Treatment plan.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
The agency was provided technical assistance on uploading the youth school
status, grades and school attending and or performances in the education
section in MiSACWIS.
Technical assistance was also provided for the guardian, caregiver to check the
boxes on the PATP's when the report is dated.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
There was no consultation provided this reporting period.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
SIR #2021C0420015, initiated on 01/05/2021, was in violation with Rule
400.12208 (2,4) Job description. The agency is following their CAP that was
submitted on 09/17/2021.
SIR #2022C0420023, initiated on 06/30/2022, was in violation with Rules
400.12502 (1,g) Program statement, 400.12503 (2,e) Policy and procedure, and
400.12504 (2,f) eligibility requirements. The agency is following their CAP that
was submitted on 09/20/2022.
There was a CAP submitted for the Inspection that was completed on
09/15/2021. The agency was in violation with rules, ISEP and policy. They were
400.12312, 400.12418 (2, b), 400.12509 (3), ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS, Policy 722-
15, 801, and 722-08C. Overall, the agency is following their CAP that was
4

received on 09/17/2021. The agency had one repeat violation this reporting
period.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency reported that due to human error, work stressors, staff turnover, and
technology barriers the agency continues to strive for compliance with all rules,
policies and contract requirement. The main concern is to maintain the current
staff and to ensure all vacancies are filled.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted their annual budget and the report for the tax return.
Budget and tax returns showed no negative balances.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed were very engaging regarding their agency. They work for
the agency because they get support from their supervisors, administrator, and
co-workers. They would not change anything other than making sure they have
a full staff at all times and the pay scale.
Description of Agency Walk Through
There were no safety issues noted.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety issue concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
